ALL-SINGAPORE CHINESE SECONDARY STUDENTS/PARENTS ASSOCIATION
(INTERVIEW WITH MINISTER FOR EDUCATION)
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


2.31 p.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Mr Speaker, Sir, last Thursday, 14th December, 1961, a delegation of seven, purporting to represent an organisation styled the "All-Singapore Chinese Secondary Students/Parents Association" called on me. I met them for about two hours together with my Parliamentary Secretary and two senior officials of my Ministry. Although there was no mention of this meeting in the English Press, both the Sin Chew Jit Poh and the Nanyang Siang Pau issues of 15th December, 1961, carried a report of the Press conference which they gave after the interview, and there are indications that this organisation will persist in its agitation over the recent examination boycott issue. Also, since the new

Column: 2504

school year is due to begin a fortnight from today, and in the meantime graduation ceremonies and tea parties are being held in various Chinese secondary schools whilst the proposed Commission of Inquiry into the examination boycott has yet to be appointed, I feel it my duty, Sir, to acquaint this House of what transpired vis-a-vis the interview.

    On Wednesday, 13th December, I received a registered letter in Chinese from a certain Tan Kong Eng stating that a delegation of seven representatives of the "All-Singapore Chinese Secondary Students/Parents Association" would call on me on 14th of December at 10 a.m. to discuss - this, Sir, is the English equivalent: I quote - "matters concerning the change of system in the Chinese secondary schools with a view to arriving at an amicable settlement". The letter said that as the matter concerned the development of Chinese education, the Minister should spare some time for discussion though he might be very busy. After the interview, it was agreed that they would go back to re-discuss what had transpired at this interview and that they could come back again for another discussion, if necessary. I advised them that, in the meantime, it would be desirable to avoid issuing Press statements until the matter was resolved to mutual satisfaction.

    But, Sir, I see in the 15th December, 1961, issue of both the Sin Chew Jit Poh and the Nanyang Siang Pau that a Press conference was held immediately after the interview, it was reported inter alia - here again, Sir, I quote the English equivalent:

    'We wish to reiterate the nature of our representation. We would seriously point out that this delegation was created by the "All Singapore Chinese Secondary Students/Parents Association" to maintain and protect Chinese education, to look after the personal welfare of our children, to find a reasonable solution to the problem of changing the Chinese secondary school system. These are the responsibilities entrusted to us by over 2,000 parents.'

What, in fact, is the true character of this committee of seven, who purport to represent the "All-Singapore Chinese Secondary Students/Parents Association"? It should be remembered that the

Column: 2505

meeting of 2,000 so-called parents held in the Chinese High School on Sunday, 3rd December, 1961, was convened by the so-called Action Committee of Students who boycotted the Government Secondary IV Examination on the issue that it was an "unreasonable condition" for Government to insist that only those who pass the Government Secondary IV Examination can present themselves for the Government Upper Secondary II Examination, which examination will only take place for the first time at the end of 1963. This normal educational practice and procedure has been accepted without question by 27 principals of Chinese secondary schools and the Singapore Chinese Schools Committee-Teacher Association. Of the seven representatives who met me, four of them claimed that they were not able to fill up a form in Chinese which I asked them to complete, and they had to be assisted to do so by my officials. They were Mr Lee Swee Seng, Madam Liu Geok Lan, Madam Yap Kim Lan and Madam Tan Wei Lam. It was a simple form, Sir, that I asked them to fill up in order to check on their credentials before the interview got started. Briefly, it asked for the name of the student each represented, his school and class, the relationship of the representative to the student, his occupation and address, whether he or she is a Singapore citizen and his or her signature. They were at first reluctant to complete this form and it took me nearly 15 minutes to persuade them they must establish their credentials. At one stage, they insisted on calling in the Press. Later on, they even asked for an adjournment to consider this matter, but I said it was unnecessary and that all I wanted to know was whom they were representing.

    Now, Sir, of this committee of seven which claims to represent "Parents of all students of Chinese secondary schools", not a single one is, in fact, a genuine parent of a student studying in a Secondary IV class. One of the representatives, Madam Yap Kim Lan claimed to have a step-daughter in a Secondary IV class in Chung Cheng High School but was unable to say which of the 15 Secondary IV classes

Column: 2506

she was in. However, a tedious search was made of the school registers by my officials, but they failed to find the student's name that was supplied. Two of them did have some relationship with Secondary IV students, namely, Tan Kong Eng and Ong Ban Song as brothers of students studying in Secondary IV classes at Sin Min High School and Chung Cheng High School respectively. The third, Lee Swee Seng, is not even a relative but a "friend" of a Secondary IV student in Chung Cheng High School. Of the remaining three representatives who had nothing to do with Secondary IV students, one claimed to have a younger sister studying in Secondary II at Yoke Eng High School, and two others claimed to have daughters studying in Secondary III at Chung Hwa Girls High School and Kong Yiong High School.

    It will be seen, therefore, that this committee of seven cannot claim to speak for parents of Secondary IV students who boycotted the examination - not to say of all parents of students in Chinese secondary schools. They were so told at this interview. Contrast them with the genuine parents who accompanied their children to the examination centres despite the picketing and thus proved that the boycott and the picketing was organised by a minority of agitators who misinformed the students and others over the issue involved.

    We have, Sir, the following interesting additional information on three of the seven representatives. Firstly, Tan Kong Eng - the man who wrote the letter seeking the interview - is also known as Tan Kwong Yong. He is the brother and not the parent of Tan Kwong Buck, aged 19, a Secondary IV student of Sin Mm High School, who was a member of the student delegation which met my Parliamentary Secretary on 16th November, 1961. Secondly, Ong Ban Song was a Communist terrorist who surrendered to the Johore police on 8th March, 1954, after deserting from the 5th Independent Platoon at Kulai and was released on 31st May, 1954. He has been Welfare Officer of the Kampong Kembangan Branch of the Singapore Rural Residents

Column: 2507

Association and its General Affairs Officer since June 1961. His younger brother, Ong Ban Kim, aged 17, is in Secondary IVA of Chung Cheng High School and was one of the picketers. Thirdly, Lee Swee Seng, also known as Wai Tau, is an active supporter of the Barisan Sosialis. His Secondary IV student friend, who boycotted the Government examination, Ng Way Ten aged 21, of Chung Cheng High School, Secondary IVK class, was one of the spokesmen of the student delegation which met my Parliamentary Secretary on 16th November, 1961 and an active picket leader at the Ministry of Education. It will be remembered, Sir, that this student delegation was responsible for distorting what actually took place at the same interview with my Parliamentary Secretary. And their circular letter dated 17th November, 1961, which was distributed to students and Members of the public, first received prominence in the second issue of Barisan, organ of the Barisan Sosialis, on 22nd November, 1961, which I made mention of in my earlier statement.

    In order that the House may have a true picture of what transpired at this interview last Thursday, and to avoid misrepresentation, I wish to summarise the position as follows. These so-called parents' representatives were told that the Ministry could not agree to their request to do away with the so-called "unreasonable condition" - that only those who pass the Government Secondary IV examination can present themselves for the Government Upper Secondary II examination, which will not be held till the end of 1963. It was suggested by one representative, Sir, that the "unreasonable condition" was not accepted by the Singapore Chinese Schools Committee-Teacher Association hut that it was surreptitiously inserted into the Press statement by the Ministry without the knowledge of the Committee-Teacher Association. This is not true. After a two-hour discussion over the issues, agreement was reached and a joint Press statement as published in the Sin Chew Jit Poh and the Nanyang

Column: 2508

Siang Pau on 6th October, 1961, was first read out by my Parliamentary Secretary in the presence not only of eight members of the Committee-Teacher Association but also members of the Press. There is a photo, Sir, in the Sin Chew Jit Poh showing the Parliamentary Secretary in the act of reading the agreed Press statement. After this the President of the Committee-Teacher Association, Mr Ko Teck Kin, put his signature to the document to signify his agreement to the joint statement, which fact was also reported in the Nanyang Siang Pan of the same day. For purpose of record, the names of the eight members of the Committee-Teacher Association who were present that day were:-

    Ko Teck Kin

    Kheng Chin Hock

    Lim Keng Lian

    Foo Chee Fong

    Madam Lin Fang Lan

    Kao Hung Keng

    Tan Choon Teng

    Phua Chay Long

One representative of the so-called parents suggested holding a referendum amongst all Chinese secondary school students over the so-called "unreasonable condition". This could not be accepted as no government in the world would consult immature school children on educational policies. What would be the situation if a referendum were asked on whether there should be examinations at all? I think it was indicated by the Member for Farrer Park that the likely result would be "No".

    Sir, from the evidence we had about this so-called parents' representatives and the students' boycott, it is now clear that the whole operation of the examination boycott was part of the pro-Communist campaign to stir up feelings against the Government. After the boy-Cotters had failed in their attempt to wreck the Government Secondary IV examination, they organised a four-day "student congregation" from 5th December to 8th December to have so-called "collective life" and "Hsueh-hsi", similar to the 1956 period, at the Chinese

Column: 2509

High School and Chung Cheng High School. During these so-called "Hsueh-hsi" sessions, student leaders read aloud the article on examination boycott from the Barisan, the organ of the Barisan Sosialis. At these sessions student leaders reminded those present of the Communist-inspired student movement which began on 13th May, 1954. One of the girl student leaders asked those present not to be afraid of brutal force and cited the May 13 incident as a worthy example to emulate. She urged that they should consolidate and prepare for a more bitter struggle ahead. She stressed, Sir, that in this Assembly, instead of debating the question of merger, the Government, she alleged had brought in the motion for police protection for parents of students taking the Government examination in order to divert the main issue with the hope that this bogus merger proposal could be carried through. Students were also taught to sing the following songs, "The May 13 March", "Holding Hands", "Praised be the month of May", "May 13 Remembrance Song". For the Current Affairs test, the following questions were among those set for verbal answer:-

    (l) Why is it that the education policy of the P.A.P. Government is similar to that of the Lim Yew Hock Government? Give reasons.

    (2) Is there any difference between "citizen" and "national"?

    (3) What difference is there between a "complete "merger" and "Malaysia"?

    (4) Is there any dissimilarity in the education policy of the Singapore Government and that of the Federation Government?

    (5) Why do we boycott the examination and what is the reaction of the public?

    Sir, it is clear that student agitators were making use of innocent students to whip up sentiment against merger, and this boycott was no doubt part of an overall anti-Government campaign inspired by pro-Communist elements to subvert the Government and to campaign against merger. As we have said from the very beginning, this has become not an educational issue but a political issue engineered by Communists and pro-Communists with the ulterior motive

Column: 2510

of discrediting the Government. Fortunately their efforts failed dismally. The great majority of students, assisted by their parents, resisted the campaign of intimidation and vilification mounted by these misinformed youths. By sitting for the Government examination, the majority of students have exposed the true nature of pro-Communist agitation as an attempt to sacrifice students for their selfish political interest. For the first time in Malayan history, Sir, the Chinese students of their own free will and initiative have resisted the Communist-inspired campaign and defeated it thoroughly.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): The Minister made some reference to the Barisan Sosialis. He said that there was one Lee Swee . . . something, an active -

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: Active supporter.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: - an active supporter of the Barisan Sosialis. Can we ask the Minister if he knows that there are the large numbers in Singapore who are active supporters of the Barisan Sosialis? Does he know that there are thousands and thousands actively supporting the Barisan Sosialis?

    Mr Speaker: Order. That does not arise on the statement.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Well, we are glad in having so many active supporters. He also mentioned something about our Barisan being quoted by students holding their Hsueh-hsi classes. I think not only the students, Sir -

    Mr Speaker: Is the Member asking a question?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Is there anything wrong, Sir, in our Barisan being quoted? He used to quote a lot from the P.A.P. Petir before.

    Mr Speaker: A question has been asked. Does the Minister wish to reply?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I just thought, Sir, that to reply to the Member for Queenstown, all that was necessary for

Column: 2511

me in a ministerial statement is to make mention of facts: that so-and-so used this, and students were using that in their Hsueh-hsi sessions.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): If it please you, Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a motion standing in my name and that of the Member for Jon Chiat. In the circumstances of the somewhat explosive atmosphere around education, I have indicated to the Minster this morning by letter that I would appreciate it if he would let me know, since Government had indicated it was as anxious as I to appoint a Commission, whether he would, in fact, make a ministerial statement appointing a Commission so that we could avoid a debate wherein this educational policy might take on unhappy political slants, Sir. I am anxious that we should avoid that and have a non-political approach. Would the Minister indicate whether that is under consideration?

    Mr Yong Nyuk Lin: I wish to assure the Member for Anson that his request is under consideration.

3.00 p.m.

    Head D8 -

    Dr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head D8 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1.

    Sir, there are certain large blocks of property in a very densely populated city area which will be reverting to the Government at the end of a ninety-nine year lease. I remember at one time that a certain school was offered a piece of that property. I think some of the leases might be expiring at the end of this year or at the end of the next two or three years. Sir, this will give the Government an opportunity to remove some of the very unhealthy areas there and do some clearance work. At the same time, we realise very well the great difficulty in resettling the people affected. I remember visiting one family living in a very dingy and poorly ventilated room and the rent was $20 to $30 per room in that area. I asked them why they did not go for the Housing Board houses, where they could get similar accommodation for about $20. The answer was that they wanted to be near their work. "Besides, if we go for the Housing Board houses in Queenstown, it means more transport money, loss of time; so we would rather pay even $10 per month more than go over there." Sir, these are some of the difficulties, and we wonder whether the Minister has made plans on the development of the area and how he proposes to resettle these people.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I do not think we can rebuild the slums of Singapore just on the basis of property reverting to the State on the expiry of the ninety-nine year lease. It is only bits of property here and there and not a continuous purchase of property that will revert to the State. But I think the Member for Tanglin has raised a very vital issue which has been exercising the minds of Government for some time. But we do not see it as something that we can do as part of the present Development Plan, because the Housing Board has enough on its hands to carry out its own housing programme

Column: 2513

which will be mainly outside the centre of the city. But obviously something must be done about the slums of Singapore. The building are old and dilapidated and are not being maintained. One possible approach which the Government has been thinking about is not only to make use of the properties which revert to their ownership at the end of the leases but also to buy up all properties in areas to be re-developed. But this is going to be a massive operation. Certainly it will cost several hundred millions of dollars, and it will perhaps take more than a decade to complete. We have asked the United Nations to send a specialist who can advice us on how to proceed with this long-term development of the city itself, how we can get rid of these slum buildings, and how in their places a proper and modern city could be built. But as I said, this is really a rather long-term problem, something perhaps for consideration in the second Five-Year Development Plan.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware that in the past, when these 99-year leases expired, the Government renewed them on a similar basis with certain conditions which the Minister calls in a haphazard fashion. There are certain areas in Singapore, Sir, where a 99-year lease is granted in respect of large tracts of land on which a very great number of houses stand. Is the Government in fact, pursuing the old tradition of renewing these leases when they expire? And secondly, whether they would survey the problem, say, for the next ten years, to have an adequate understanding of the areas that would, in fact, fall due, and have an overall plan before issuing fresh leases in respect of those which already expired.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: To the best of my belief, properties which revert to the State remain with the State. They are not being leased out to new holders. As regards the long-term development plan to rebuild the city, I have explained, in reply to the question of the Member for Tanglin, that we have taken note of this problem. We have made preliminary steps towards solving it. But, as I have

Column: 2514

said, it is going to be a long-term process.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee: I withdraw, Sir.

    Head D13 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head D13 bereduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1.

    Sir, I have tabled in all 206 amendments under the Development Estimates. Sir, they have been put in because the Standing Orders require me to give notice if I want to raise any matter on which I would like to ask questions or seek information. But in order to cut this debate short, Sir, I think it would be convenient if you would allow me to roam over the Development Estimates. If I get satisfaction, I will therefore not find it necessary to move all the other amendments standing in my name.

    The Chairman: If it is convenient, certainly.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Thank you, Sir. Sir, that being so, I would like, first of all, to say that from a close study of the Development Estimates which we have here for 1963 - it would appear that little work has been put into it. With only one exception, it is a very convenient reproduction of the 1962 Development Estimates, with different amounts estimated to be spent in 1963. Sir, the 1962 Development Estimates have at least been prepared with care, giving details of plan costs, revised plan costs, estimated expenditure up to 31st December, 1961, estimated expenditure in 1962, expenditure required to complete, and notes. The 1963 Development Estimates, Sir, just show plan costs, revised plan costs and estimated expenditure in 1963. These, therefore, do not give a complete picture. The 1963 Estimates have to be studied alongside the 1962 Estimates in order to have a clear understanding of what the 1963 Development Estimates are about. Sir, may I touch on this? From a close study of the two Development Estimates, it would appear that the

Column: 2515



1963 Development Estimates can be divided into five classes. The first class is that under the item, a full vote has already been provided for in 1962, and yet for 1963 a token provision of $10 is asked for. I find it difficult try understand this. As far as my little knowledge goes of how budgets are drawn up, when one puts in a token vote of $10, it means that while the principle has been accepted, as in the case of the hospital at Kandang Kerbau which is to be built, the details have yet to be studied or finalised. But in this case of a token vote in 1963, it is an extra $10 that is asked for on an item for which full provision has already been provided in 1962. Therefore, I say, Sir, that these 1963 Development Estimates have been prepared with little or no work at all. It makes it difficult for the Opposition to understand and appreciate what is behind the motive in presenting as a rush matter the Development Estimates that do not coincide with the regular yearly Development Estimates, where full details are given. The Government wants a rush job of this for reasons which they have already explained. We have accepted those reasons. But they have made it more difficult for the Opposition to understand what they are driving at. That is one of it. One class is where full estimates have already been provided in 1962, and yet for 1963, a token provision is asked for. A token provision of $10, as far as we understand it, and as has been explained by the Minister in this House, it always put in where a principle has been accepted, but the details of the works have not been finalised or completed. How could it be a token provision when the work has already started, and the full amount has already been given? That is one class.

    The second class is that full votes have already been provided in 1962, and yet for 1963 some more money is asked for. I think there are over a hundred items where full votes have already been provided in 1962.

Column: 2516



3.15 p.m.

    Just take a case in point, the multi-storey car park. Now, for 1962, $2 million has been provided, and the cost of that multi-storey car park is estimated to cost $2 million. Yet for 1963, $1 million is put in. Of course, I can understand, Sir, that $1 million could be a revote, because the Government does not expect that the full amount could have been paid or that the car park could have been completed in 1962. But then in 1962, in cases where it is a revote, it is clearly stated that the vote asked for is a revote. That is in 1962, where actual facts are given, it is revote. But for 1963, just "Multi-storey Car Park, Plan Cost $2 million, Revised Plan Cost $2 million, amount asked for $1 million." If we were to approve that $1 million, it could mean that the Government could use that extra million to pay for a multi-storey car park over and above the revised plan cost. Unless it is put in the notes column that it is a revote, we can have no control. Sir, it seems that the Ministers cannot be serious about it. They want the Opposition to vote a million dollars for them to put in an extra storey.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): I do not want it.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, they are now trying to tell a cock-and-bull story about the way they present this Budget which-they say - what did the Minster for Finance say? He explained in page 37, paragraph 3 ["First copy" of the Hansard]:

    'To settle the details of allocation of votes and revenue between State and Central Government. additional work will devolve on Treasury officials and those Ministries affected by transfers of responsibility, and it is not likely that the 1963 Budget will be ready in time. This may well expose the Government to criticism. There might even be a loss of confidence in the administration. For this reason and in fairness to the administration, I will be asking the House to approve a vote on account for the first six months of 1963. I also intend to ask approval for the Development Estimates for the whole of 1963.'

    "In fairness to the administration"- May I say to the administration, in fairness to the Opposition, that they must

Column: 2517

present something that contains full details and not present something with no details at all and ask us to vote for it, as I have tried to explain in the case of this multi-storey car park. If we were to approve that vote of $1 million, although in fairness to the Government it means a revote, it means we would give the Government the authority to spend $1 million over and above the $2 million asked for in 1962. Sir, that is the second class.

    The third class is this. In 1962, you will find that the revised plan cost is so much; so much will have been spent by the 31st December, 1961, and a vote is asked for in 1962, and there is still some more money required to complete. Therefore, that money required to complete would, of course, have to be found in 1963. But then in the 1963 Development Estimates, what is put in to complete the work is more than what is inserted in the 1962 Budget as required to complete. Take a simple item, Civil Aviation. [Interruption] That happens to be the first one. Sub-Head 9, Passenger Terminal Building. According to the 1962 Budget, what is required to complete this sub-head is $1,140,000. But for 1963, the vote asked for is $2,140,000, which is $1 million more. And yet there is no explanation at all in the space provided for notes. Sir, if we were just to consider the 1963 Development Estimates without bothering to check every item bit by bit with the 1962 Estimates, we would not know. It would just disclose that the cost of the Passenger Terminal Building is $4.8 million, the revised plan cost is $3.14 million, and what is asked for for 1963 is $2.14 million. It does not give the true story.

    The third class is that the vote asked for in 1963 is much more than what is required to complete the work, according to the 1962 Budget.

    There is another class, Sir, and this is really very funny. For 1962, $10, a lot of $10, that is to say, a token vote of $10 to say that they want to build a hospital, but the details have not yet been completed or finalised or worked out. Therefore, a token vote of $10. And our approving a token vote of $10 for 1962 will allow the Government to go ahead with

Column: 2518

the scheme and to work out plans for whatever project the token vote is for. And for 1963, yet another token vote is asked for. That shows they do not want to do any work in 1962.
